For the interpretation we would need to keep in mind the direction of the causality between the two variables. The population count alone does not explain the attitude towrds immigrantion alone. While higher populated areas can influence the attitude, it is also possible, that these areas attract a more diverse population and therefore influence the attitude. 

The principle of revers causation is also an aspect, since as mentioned before the general attitude on immigration attracts more people in general and therefore a more diverse community.

The regression analysis can reveal associations between variables, however it cannot establish causation from observational data alone. To do an interpretation of the Population and attitude towards immigration as a causal effect we would require additional methodologies, such as natural experiments or longitudinal studies.

column11: No - correlation does not equal causation, even though we heuristically might think that higher-educated citizens that tend to live in densely populated urban areas often hold pro-immigration stances. There could be a selection bias, i.e., the pollers could have selected respondents from different municipalities (groups) that have systematic differences between them (e.g., many differences across various measured and unmeasured variables). Moreover, there could be confounding variables - related to my first point regarding selection bias - that have a causal effect on both Extra_ImmigrationIsAThreat and populationCount. For instance, it is conceivable that a variable such as economic status could be associated with both populationCount and ImmigrationIsAThreat, since people in urban areas typically are more affluent than people in rural areas and typically hold pro-immigration sentiments in comparison with less afluent people.
